Leonardo da Vinci: Bringing back the Renaissance mastermind to the present day would be an incredible opportunity to learn from one of history's most brilliant minds. Da Vinci was a true polymath, excelling in art, science, engineering, and mathematics. He could share his insights on creativity, innovation, and problem-solving, and inspire a new generation of thinkers and doers. Plus, he could show us how to build those flying machines he always talked about!

Cleopatra: As the last pharaoh of ancient Egypt, Cleopatra was a powerful and intelligent leader who knew how to navigate complex political situations. She could offer valuable insights on diplomacy, leadership, and gender empowerment. With her vast knowledge of ancient Egyptian culture and history, she could also share her perspectives on the impact of colonialism and the importance of cultural preservation. And who knows, maybe she could even give us some tips on how to get what we want from Mark Antony!

Albert Einstein: As one of the greatest minds in physics, Einstein's theories and discoveries revolutionized our understanding of the universe. He could explain the mysteries of relativity, quantum mechanics, and the behavior of matter and energy in a way that's easy to understand. Plus, he could offer insights on the intersection of science and philosophy, and how our understanding of the universe can inform our understanding of the human condition. And who knows, maybe he could even help us solve some of the world's most pressing problems, like climate change and energy sustainability.

Frida Kahlo: As a groundbreaking artist and feminist icon, Kahlo's vibrant and emotive paintings offer a unique window into the experiences of women and the struggles of the human condition. She could share her perspectives on the intersection of art and politics, and how her art was a way for her to navigate the challenges of her own life. With her unflinching honesty and creative vision, she could inspire a new generation of artists and feminists to embrace their own voices and tell their own stories.
